importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau reported on the rise of TRAPs starting in the 1990s, with continued use into the 2020s, indicating a long-standing trend that is now being challenged by new legislation.

keyTakeAways: Employers may require employees to repay benefits like training or bonuses if they leave before a specified period, known as 'stay-or-pay' agreements.
Such agreements are criticized as abusive, especially when applied to lower-income workers and in industries like healthcare, transportation, and retail.
Training repayment agreements (TRAPs) are often enforced even when training was unnecessary or of low quality, and their existence can pressure employees into staying.

A new California law, signed by Governor Gavin Newsom, bans repayment for on-the-job training (except in approved apprentice programs) and for benefits when employees are laid off without cause or when jobs are eliminated.
The law allows retention bonuses, tuition reimbursement for transferable credentials, and signing bonuses—but requires repayment to be prorated if the employee leaves early.
Employees must be allowed to take bonuses or reimbursements at departure, not at hire, reducing financial risk upon leaving.
The stay period is capped at two years, with no interest accrual, limiting employer financial leverage.
The law is praised by labor groups like the California Nurses Association for reducing worker entrapment and promoting job mobility.
Other states like New York have introduced similar legislation, suggesting a potential national movement to regulate stay-or-pay agreements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article discusses how some employers require employees to repay benefits such as training or bonuses if they leave a job before a specified period — known as stay-or-pay agreements. These agreements, especially training repayment agreements (TRAPs), are criticized as abusive and limiting worker mobility, particularly for lower-income workers in industries like healthcare, transportation, and retail. Research estimates that up to 8.7% of workers are affected. In response, California passed a first-in-the-nation law banning repayment for on-the-job training (except in approved apprentice programs) and for benefits when employees are laid off without cause, with the law taking effect on January 1, 2026. The law still allows certain retention bonuses and tuition reimbursement for transferable credentials, but with prorated repayment and a two-year stay limit. The move is seen as a step toward protecting employee autonomy and financial freedom, and it may inspire similar legislation in other states like New York.
title: When You Have to Pay Your Employer Money If You Quit Your Job
